title: What is the Roman initiation and its significance in the Western tradition?
first_phrase: In this section, the author addresses the misconceptions about initiation in the Western tradition. The author challenges the belief that initiation requires pacifism and love for all. Instead, the author argues that initiation requires adherence to principles of justice and ethics. The author also addresses the objection that Rome did not have a tradition of mystery schools, pointing out that initiation takes different forms in different cultures. The discussion includes a mention of the Roman god of initiation, Janus.

last_phrase: In conclusion, while there may not be exact replicas of the Eleusinian or Isiac Mysteries in Roman tradition, the presence of the god Janus as the guardian of initiatory gates and keys implies the existence of a Roman initiation center with its own unique adaptations. It is important to acknowledge the diversity of initiatory expressions across time and place, and not limit ourselves to preconceived notions of what initiation should look like.
